## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 298, 329, 314]]<|/det|>

Candidates answer on the Question Paper.

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 390, 388, 407]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 715, 432]]<|/det|>
Write your centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 432, 325, 447]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 447, 502, 462]]<|/det|>
You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 462, 504, 477]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 476, 380, 491]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 502, 255, 516]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 516, 361, 531]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 530, 767, 546]]<|/det|>
You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 555, 604, 571]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 570, 759, 586]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 755, 91]]<|/det|> A student is determining the weight of a metre rule using a balancing method. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 364, 121]]<|/det|> Fig. 1.1 shows the apparatus. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[133, 133, 856, 268]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 287, 532, 306]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 318, 920, 368]]<|/det|> The student places the metre rule on the pivot. He places the load P on the metre rule at the \(90.0 \text{cm}\) mark. Keeping load P at the \(90.0 \text{cm}\) mark, he adjusts the position of the metre rule on the pivot so that the metre rule is as near as possible to being balanced. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 381, 620, 399]]<|/det|> He records the distance \(a\) from the \(90.0 \text{cm}\) mark to the pivot. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 412, 620, 430]]<|/det|> He records the distance \(b\) from the pivot to the \(50.0 \text{cm}\) mark. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 443, 920, 476]]<|/det|> He repeats the steps, placing the load P at the \(85.0 \text{cm}\), the \(80.0 \text{cm}\), the \(75.0 \text{cm}\) and the \(70.0 \text{cm}\) marks. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 490, 425, 507]]<|/det|> The readings are shown in Table 1.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 520, 539, 537]]<|/det|> Table 1.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[361, 551, 635, 705]]<|/det|>
\(a/\text {cm}\)\(b/\text {cm}\)

18.017.2
16.014.1
13.011.8
10.59.5

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A student is investigating the rate of cooling of water under different conditions. A greater rate of cooling occurs if there is a greater change in the temperature during the same period of time.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 437, 136]]<|/det|>
Fig. 3.1 shows some of the apparatus.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[262, 146, 720, 380]]<|/det|>

<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 425, 146, 444]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 425, 920, 460]]<|/det|>
The thermometer in Fig.3.2 shows the room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) at the beginning of the experiment. Record \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\).

<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 528, 534, 546]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 590, 613, 608]]<|/det|>
The student pours \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into the beaker.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 621, 920, 655]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 667, 920, 700]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 327, 920, 361]]<|/det|> The student repeats the procedure using a metal can, painted matt black, in place of the beaker. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 374, 463, 392]]<|/det|> The readings are shown in Table 3.2. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 405, 181, 422]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 405, 693, 422]]<|/det|> Complete the column headings in Table 3.1 and in Table 3.2. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 405, 920, 422]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 435, 180, 453]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 435, 680, 453]]<|/det|> Look carefully at the readings in Table 3.1 and in Table 3.2. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 465, 653, 484]]<|/det|> Tick the box to show your conclusion from the readings. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 491, 240, 586]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[270, 496, 920, 515]]<|/det|> The water in the beaker has a greater rate of cooling than the water in the can. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[270, 527, 920, 546]]<|/det|> The water in the beaker has a smaller rate of cooling than the water in the can. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[270, 559, 920, 593]]<|/det|> There is no significant difference between the rates of cooling of the water in the beaker and the can. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 592, 920, 610]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 621, 180, 640]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 621, 625, 640]]<|/det|> Justify your conclusion by reference to the readings. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 744, 920, 763]]<|/det|> [2]

<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
A student in another school carries out the experiment and reports that the rate of cooling of the water in the can is different from the rate of cooling of the water in the beaker. He plans a change to the experiment to find out whether this difference in the rates of cooling is caused by

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 149, 170, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>*</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 149, 920, 183]]<|/det|>
the matt black surface of the can being a better radiator of thermal energy than the shiny surface of the beaker

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 196, 170, 214]]<|/det|>
<label>*</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 196, 920, 230]]<|/det|>
the metal of the can being a better conductor of thermal energy than the material of the beaker.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 243, 183, 261]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 243, 824, 261]]<|/det|>

2. ..........................................................................................................................................

<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 412, 181, 431]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 490, 917, 507]]<|/det|>
..........................................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 520, 217, 539]]<|/det|>
<label>2.</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 551, 917, 567]]<|/det|>
..........................................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 567, 920, 586]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 598, 907, 616]]<|/det|>
State one precaution that you would take in order to record accurate temperature readings.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 668, 920, 686]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 692, 920, 710]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
A student is investigating the work required to pull a box containing some masses up a sloping wooden board. Fig. 4.1 shows the board and the box.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 918, 152]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate how the work required to pull the box up the slope depends on the mass of the box and its contents.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 165, 480, 183]]<|/det|>
Work done is calculated using the equation:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 196, 685, 214]]<|/det|>
work done = force \(\times\) distance moved in the direction of the force.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 227, 547, 245]]<|/det|>
The following apparatus is available to the students:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 259, 295, 275]]<|/det|>
a wooden board

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 274, 465, 291]]<|/det|>
a box with a length of string attached

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 289, 480, 306]]<|/det|>
a selection of masses that fit in the box

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 304, 260, 320]]<|/det|>
a metre rule

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 320, 339, 337]]<|/det|>
an electronic balance.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 351, 324, 368]]<|/det|>
In your plan, you should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 382, 138, 400]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 382, 512, 400]]<|/det|>
list any other apparatus that you would use

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 414, 134, 432]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 414, 920, 446]]<|/det|>
explain briefly how you would carry out the investigation, including the measurements you would take

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 460, 134, 479]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 460, 532, 479]]<|/det|>
state the key variables that you would control

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 494, 134, 512]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 494, 920, 526]]<|/det|>
draw a suitable table, with column headings, to show how you would display your readings (you are not required to enter any readings in the table)
